questions.text: A 32 year female suffering from End Stage Renal Disease underwent Renal Transplantation. She conceived 2 years later. In the 8th month of gestation, she developed Intrahepatic cholestasis. Which of the following immunosuppressants is most likely to lead to cholestasis?
questions.solution:
Some drugs that impede canalicular transport of bile acids may lead to intrahepatic cholestasis. For example, cholestatic jaundice has been observed in pregnant women taking azathioprine following renal transplantation.

Optionwise explanations:

a. Prednisone

  • While prednisone is widely used for immunosuppression, it is not commonly associated with causing cholestasis in pregnancy.

c. Sirolimus

  • Sirolimus has liver-related side effects, but cholestasis is less frequently seen compared to azathioprine. It is also generally avoided in pregnancy due to teratogenicity.

d. Mycophenolate mofetil

  • Mycophenolate is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenic risks but is not commonly linked with cholestasis.

See the table below:

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Azathioprine has the most notable association with liver-related complications, including cholestasis, especially in individuals with predisposing factors such as pregnancy or underlying liver disease.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses shows the highest incidence of cholestatic changes in the liver?
questions.solution:
Chronic hepatitis C is associated with a significantly increased risk of cholestasis, which may be as high as 20-fold among women who are hepatitis C RNA positive.

Options:

a. Hepatitis A virus

  • Hepatitis A can cause liver inflammation but cholestatic hepatitis is uncommon.

b. Hepatitis B virus

  • Hepatitis B can lead to chronic liver disease, but cholestatic changes are less frequent compared to Hepatitis C.

d. Hepatitis E virus

  • Hepatitis E is typically associated with acute liver disease, especially in pregnancy, but cholestasis is less commonly observed compared to Hepatitis C.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Hepatitis C virus is associated with chronic liver disease and has the highest incidence of cholestatic changes in the liver among the listed viruses.

"Tips & Tricks": Remember Hepatitis 'C' is associated with all the following 'C's:

Cancer (Hepatocellular carcinoma)

Carrier state

Chronic hepatitis

Cirrhosis

Cholestasis

choices.text: Lamivudine has been found to significantly decrease the risk of fetal HBV infection in women with high HBV viral loads
Infants born to seropositive mothers are given HBIG very soon after birth
HBIG is accompanied by the first of a three-dose hepatitis B recombinant vaccine
The American Academy of Pediatrics considers maternal HBV infection a contraindication to breast feeding

questions.text: A 25 year old G1P0 woman is found to be HBV seropositive on her booking visit. Which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Although virus is present in breast milk, the incidence of transmission is not lowered by formula feeding.
  • The American Academy of Pediatrics does not consider maternal HBV infection a contraindication to breast feeding.
  • To curb vertical transmission, newborns of seropositive mothers are given hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG) plus the first of a three-dose hepatitis B recombinant vaccine series very soon after birth.
  • In the absence of HBV immunoprophylaxis, 10 to 20 percent of women positive for HBsAg transmit viral infection to their infant
  • As a second transmission-prevention practice, the CDC and numerous societies now recommend antiviral therapy to decrease viral levels in gravidas whose viral load exceeds 106 to 108 copies/mL. The antiviral therapy includes drugs like lamivudine, tenofovir, telbivudine etc.

Optionwise explanation:

a. Lamivudine has been found to significantly decrease the risk of fetal HBV infection in women with high HBV viral loads

  • This is correct. Lamivudine, an antiviral drug, reduces the risk of transmission in women with high viral loads.

b. Infants born to seropositive mothers are given HBIG very soon after birth

  • Correct. Hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) is administered to prevent vertical transmission.

c. HBIG is accompanied by the first of a three-dose hepatitis B recombinant vaccine

  • Correct. This is the standard protocol to prevent HBV transmission.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Breast feeding is not contraindicated, unless baby have contra indications like galactosaemia

choices.text: Congenital heart block developed almost exclusively in fetuses of women with antibodies to the SS-A or SS-B antigens
Fetal cardiac monitoring should be performed between 18 and 26 weeks' gestation in pregnancies with either of these antibodies
The cardiac lesion is permanent, and a pacemaker is generally necessary
Maternal administration of corticosteroids, plasma exchange, or intravenous immunoglobulin reduces the risk of congenital heart block.

questions.text: A 38 year old primigravida, known case of SLE, gives birth to a male child. On examination, the baby had severe bradycardia. The paediatrician diagnosed it as a case of congenital heart block. Which of the following statements about congenital heart block is NOT true?
questions.solution:
• Congenital heart block develops almost exclusively in fetuses of women with antibodies to the SS-A or SS-B antigens
  • For women with anti-SS-B and anti-SS-A antibodies, fetal cardiac monitoring is performed between 18 and 26 weeks' gestation.

Optionwise explanation:

b. Fetal cardiac monitoring should be performed between 18 and 26 weeks' gestation in pregnancies with either of these antibodies

  • This is true. Regular monitoring is essential during this time frame to detect any arrhythmias early.

c. The cardiac lesion is permanent, and a pacemaker is generally necessary

  • if significant bradycardia is present.

d. Maternal administration of corticosteroids, plasma exchange, or intravenous immunoglobulin reduces the risk of congenital heart block.

  • This is NOT true. While these treatments may be used in management, they do not significantly reduce the risk of developing congenital heart block in the fetus

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Congenital heart block is closely associated with maternal antibodies to SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La).

choices.text: May involve palms of the hands and/or soles of the feet

questions.text: Pruritus of obstetric cholestasis has all of the following attributes, except:
questions.solution:
• Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy (ICP) is a cause of itching during pregnancy. Associated characteristics include elevated liver enzymes (transaminases) and serum bile acids (salts).
  • Itching with ICP is usually intermittent at the outset and goes on to become constant. Pruritus begins first in the abdomen and spreads to involve the entire trunk and very specifically occurs on the palms and soles.
  • The itching ranges from mild to severe and bothers the patient most at night.

Optionwise explanation:

b. May involve palms of the hands and/or soles of the feet

  • This is true. Pruritus in obstetric cholestasis commonly affects the palms and soles.

c. Absence of a rash

  • This is true. The itching in obstetric cholestasis occurs without a rash.

d. Associated with abnormal liver function

  • This is true. Obstetric cholestasis is characterized by elevated liver enzymes and abnormal liver function tests.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Pruritis in late pregnancy specifically on palms and sole particularly at night with raised serum bile salts with low serum transaminases = intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy
  • Underlying chronic hepatitis C is associated with a significantly greater risk of developing ICP, which may be as much as 20-fold higher

Reference: Adhikari B, Hall H, Carlson K, et al. Pruritus in Pregnancy. [Updated 2023 Nov 12]

choices.text: Risk is same at all times

questions.text: Greatest risk of transmission of herpes to the fetus is in/within:
questions.solution:
Factors associated with transmission of genital herpes include:

  • the type of maternal infection (primary or recurrent)
  • the presence of transplacental maternal neutralising antibodies
  • the duration of rupture of membranes before delivery
  • the use of fetal scalp electrodes
  • the mode of delivery

The risks are greatest when a woman acquires a new infection (primary genital herpes) in the third trimester, particularly within 6 weeks of delivery, as viral shedding may persist and the baby is likely to be born before the development of protective maternal antibodies.

Optionwise explanation:

a) First trimester

While transmission can occur during the first trimester, the risk is not as high as later in pregnancy.

b) Second trimester

The risk of transmission is not at its highest during the second trimester.

d) Risk is same at all times

This is incorrect, as the risk of transmission varies depending on the timing of maternal infection.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

The greatest risk of transmission of herpes to the fetus occurs during the perinatal period, especially if the mother has an active outbreak or newly acquired herpes within 6 weeks of delivery.

Reference: RCOG guidelines on management of genital herpes in pregnancy October 2014

questions.text: A 28 year old G2P1L1 woman develops florid herpetic lesions all over her body in the third trimister. She is started on an antiviral drug by her gynaecologist. Which of the following can be a neonatal adverse effect of maternal therapy?
questions.solution:
• Management of the woman should be in line with her clinical condition and will usually involve the use of oral (or intravenous for disseminated HSV) acyclovir in standard doses (400 mg three times daily, usually for 5 days).
  • The use of acyclovir is associated with a reduction in the duration and severity of symptoms and a decrease in the duration of viral shedding.
  • Acyclovir is not licensed for use in pregnancy but is considered safe and has not been associated with an increased incidence of birth defects.
  • Transient neonatal neutropenia has been reported but no clinically significant adverse maternal or neonatal effects have been reported. Acyclovir is otherwise well tolerated in pregnancy.

Optionwise explanation:

a) Thrombocytosis

  • Thrombocytosis is an increase in platelet count and is not commonly associated with antiviral therapy for herpes.

c) Mast cell activation

  • While mast cell activation can have various effects, it is not typically a direct adverse effect of antiviral therapy in neonates.

d) Punctate basophilia

  • Punctate basophilia refers to the presence of small basophilic granules in red blood cells and is not a recognized adverse effect related to maternal antiviral treatment.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Transient neutropenia is a known potential adverse effect of antiviral medications, particularly those used for herpes simplex virus (e.g., acyclovir). Neonates may experience transient neutropenia as a result of maternal treatment.

Reference: RCOG guidelines on management of genital herpes in pregnancy October 2014

questions.text: A 25 year old G1P0 woman gets a CBC done in the third trimester. Her Hb is 13g/dl, TLC 14,000/cu mm, platelets 94,000/cu mm. LFT & RFT are normal. Her pulse is 84/min, BP 124/80 mmHg. No clinical complaints. No history of febrile illness. Which of the following is most likely?
questions.solution:
• A platelet count below the normal range is found in 8-10% of pregnancies.
  • Approximately 75% of these cases are due to a benign process of gestational thrombocytopenia; 15-20% can be attributed to hypertensive disorders; 3-4% to an immune process; and the remaining 1-2% are made up of rare constitutional thrombocytopenia, infections and haematological malignancies.
  • As the BP is in the normal range, liver function is normal HELLP is unlikely
  • In ITP (Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura) & TTP (Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic purpura), platelet levels fall much lower.

Optionwise explanations:

Options:

b. HELLP

  • HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) would usually present with elevated liver enzymes and hemolysis indicators, which are not mentioned here. The normal LFTs suggest this is unlikely.

c. ITP (Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura)

  • ITP is characterized by low platelet counts due to autoimmune destruction but may not be asymptomatic. There is typically a history of bleeding tendencies.

d. TTP (Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura)

  • TTP is a rare condition characterized by thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and often involves organ dysfunction. The absence of symptoms and normal LFTs makes this less likely.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

At a glance, Gestational thrombocytopenia is common in pregnancy, typically characterized by mild thrombocytopenia (platelet count usually >70,000/cu mm), and is often discovered incidentally with no associated symptoms.


Reference: Myers B. Thrombocytopenia in pregnancy. The Obstetrician & Gynaecologist 200977, Page no. 183

questions.text: A 27-year old G2P1L1 woman with previous LSCS is planned for elective LSCS under spinal anaesthesia at 39 weeks' gestation. Her CBC was shown to the anaesthetist, and the platelet count was low, 65000/cumm. No febrile illness. No significant past medical history. The anaesthetist recommended she is unfit for spinal anaesthesia. What imminent risk the anaesthetist is concerned about?
questions.solution:
• Thrombocytopenia, depending on its severity, has long been considered a relative or even absolute contraindication to neuraxial techniques due to a potential increased risk of spinal/epidural hematoma, a rare but dreaded complication that can result in permanent neurologic injury.
  • In the absence of additional risk factors, a platelet count of 80 x 10(9)/l is a 'safe' count for placing an epidural or spinal anaesthetic and 40 x 10(9)/l is a 'safe' count for lumbar puncture.

Options:

a. DIC (Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation)

  • DIC can lead to bleeding complications but is less directly related to the immediate risks associated with performing spinal anaesthesia.

b. Cerebral bleed

  • While low platelet counts can pose a risk for cerebral bleeding, it is not the most immediate concern in the context of spinal anaesthesia.

d. Total spinal anaesthesia

  • This is a rare complication and is not primarily related to low platelet counts

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • A low platelet count<80k significantly increases the risk of spinal epidural hematoma, a potentially serious complication that can occur if bleeding occurs in the epidural space following spinal anaesthesia.

Reference: American Society of Anaesthesiologists' guidelines on Risk of epidural hematoma with neuraxial techniques in thrombocytopenic patients

questions.text: Which of the following is not a pathognomonic feature of Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy?
questions.solution:
A normal coagulation profile is not a pathognomonic feature of AFLP, as coagulopathy is often present in this condition. In Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP), the coagulation profile is often abnormal due to liver dysfunction. This can lead to coagulopathy, which is characterized by prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). Additionally, there may be decreased levels of fibrinogen and antithrombin III, and in severe cases, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) can occur.

  • Acute fatty liver of pregnancy is an uncommon but potentially fatal complication that occurs in the third trimester or early postpartum period.
  • AFLP is characterized by microvesicular fatty infiltration of hepatocytes without any inflammation or necrosis.
  • Abnormalities in liver biochemistry include elevated serum aminotransferases (i.e., serum aspartate amino-transferase and alanine aminotransferase) levels of 300 U/L to 500 U/L..

Options:

a) Profound hypoglycemia

  • This is commonly seen in acute fatty liver of pregnancy due to impaired gluconeogenesis.

b) Hyperuricemia

  • This is also associated with acute fatty liver of pregnancy due to increased uric acid production and decreased renal clearance..

d) Deranged liver enzymes

  • Elevated liver enzymes are a hallmark of acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Features of acute fatty liver of pregnancy:-

questions.text: A 34 year old P2L2 woman attends NCD clinic for routine check up. She had a BMI of 30 kg/m2 and was evaluated with some clinical & biochemical tests. The consulting physician diagnosed her with Metabolic syndrome. Which of the following parameters is not included in the NCEP ATP III criteria of Metabolic syndrome?
questions.solution:
NCEP/ATP III criteria for the diagnosis of the metabolic syndrome include the following (diagnosis is made when three or more are present):

  • Waist circumference of more than 102 cm in men or more than 88 cm in women
  • Fasting triglyceride level of 150 mg/dL or higher
  • Blood pressure level of 130/85 mm Hg or higher
  • High-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) level of less than 40 mg/dL in men or less than 50 mg/dL in women
  • Fasting glucose level of 110 mg/dL or higher (which has been changed to 100 mg/dL to reflect revised criteria for impaired fasting glucose [IFG])

KEY TAKE AWAY:

The criteria includes FBS & not RBS.

questions.text: All of the following are physiological cardiovascular changes in pregnancy, except:
questions.solution:
Systolic murmurs not diastolic are often found in pregnancy due to increased blood flow across the valves.

Optionwise explanations:

a) Splitting of the 1st heart sound

  • This is a common physiological change due to increased blood volume and cardiac output.

c) Left axis deviation in ECG

  • Left axis deviation can occur during pregnancy due to changes in the position of the heart.

d) Mid diastolic murmur

  • This is not typically considered a normal physiological change in pregnancy and may indicate pathological conditions.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Systolic murmurs are common during pregnancy.
  • Diastolic murmurs are not common & mostly organic/pathological.
  • Normal CVS findings, normal ECG changes and clinical indicators of heart disease in pregnancy:-

questions.text: CARPREG risk score of grading morbidity & mortality associated with cardiovascular disorders, does not take into consideration which of the following parameters:
questions.solution:
Obstructive lesions of left & not right heart form one criterion of the CARPREG (Cardiac Risk in Pregnancy) score.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

CARPREG score used predict cardiac risk in pregnancy:-

Mnemonic: Remember it as "NOPE"

NYHA class > II

Obstructive lesions of left heart

Prior cardiovascular event

Ejection fraction <40%

questions.text: "Acute chest syndrome" frequently complicates which of the following hematological disorders in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
• Acute chest syndrome is a vaso-occlusive crisis of the pulmonary vasculature, commonly seen in pregnant women with sickle cell anemia.

Options:

b) Alpha thalassemia

  • While alpha thalassemia can lead to complications, acute chest syndrome is not typically associated with it.

c) Beta thalassemia

  • Similar to alpha thalassemia, beta thalassemia does not commonly lead to acute chest syndrome.

d) von Willebrand Disease

  • This condition primarily affects bleeding and clotting, not typically leading to acute chest syndrome.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Acute chest syndrome is a common and serious complication of sickle cell disease.
  • It is characterized by pleuritic chest pain, fever, cough, lung infiltrates, hypoxia, and usually bone and joint pain.
  • In addition to symptoms, radiographs show a new pulmonary infiltrate.
  • The four precipitants are infection, marrow emboli, thromboembolism, and atelectasis.

questions.text: Second most common cause of jaundice in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Obstetric cholestasis is the second most common cause of jaundice in pregnancy, the first being viral hepatitis.

a) Viral hepatitis

  • This is a most common cause of jaundice in pregnancy, particularly in endemic areas.

c) Acute fatty liver of pregnancy

  • This is a rare but serious condition that can lead to jaundice, typically occurring in the third trimester, but it is less common than obstetric cholestasis.

d) Hyperemesis gravidarum

  • While this condition can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, it is not a direct cause of jaundice.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Viral hepatitis is most common cause of jaundice in pregnancy, which is characterised by increased serum transaminases.
  • Obstetric cholestasis is the second most common cause of jaundice in pregnancy, characterized by pruritus and elevated bile acids, often occurring in the third trimester.

choices.text: Surgical field should be as haemostatic as possible
Membranes are left intact until the head is delivered through the surgical incision
Peripartum antibiotics should be administered in accordance with national guidelines for the general population
If indicated, IV Zidovudine infusion to be started just prior to the skin incision

questions.text: A 28-year old HIV positive G2P1L1 woman with previous Caesarean section has breech presentation in current pregnancy. All of the following precautionary measures are to be undertaken when an HIV positive woman is undergoing a Caesarean, except:
questions.solution:
IV Zidovudine should ideally be administered during labor or just prior to delivery, not just before the skin incision.

Optionwise explanation:

a) Surgical field should be as haemostatic as possible

  • This is important to minimize the risk of bleeding and exposure to blood.

b) Membranes are left intact until the head is delivered through the surgical incision

  • This practice helps prevent fetal exposure to maternal blood and minimizes the risk of HIV transmission.

c) Peripartum antibiotics should be administered in accordance with national guidelines for the general population

  • This is standard practice to prevent infection during and after surgery.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • For all caesarean sections, whether elective or emergency, care should be taken to ensure that the surgical field is as haemostatic as possible and, where possible, that the
    membranes are left intact until the head is delivered through the surgical incision.
  • Early cord clamping is done.
  • Peripartum antibiotics should be administered in accordance with national guidelines for the general population.
  • If indicated, IV Zidovudine infusion to be started 4 hours prior to the Caesarean.

Reference: Green Top Guideline no. 39, HIV in pregnancy, Management

choices.text: She can opt to deliver in the lateral supine position to avoid the haemodynamic problems caused by the dorsal decubitus position
Adequate pain relief must be ensured
Intravenous fluids should be administered in a controlled manner, restricted to ~ 125 ml/hr
Close watch for development of pulmonary edema in the immediate postpartum period

questions.text: A 32 year old G1P0 woman with mitral stenosis, presents to you in labour. Her vitals are stable, Pulse 90/min, BP 120/70 mmHg, RR 16/min. On examination, her cervix is 3 cm dilated, 40% effaced, membranes intact, vertex at -3 station. Uterine contractions are adequate. Which of the following is not a part of management of this woman in labour?
questions.solution:
Intravenous fluids should be administered in a controlled manner, restricted to not more than 75 ml/hr. This should keep the patient on the "dry" side.

a) She can opt to deliver in the lateral supine position to avoid the hemodynamic problems caused by the dorsal decubitus position.

  • This is a correct statement; the lateral position can help reduce pressure on the inferior vena cava and improve hemodynamics.

b) Adequate pain relief must be ensured.

  • This is also correct; managing pain is important for comfort and may help to stabilize hemodynamics.

d) Close watch for development of pulmonary edema in the immediate postpartum period.

  • This is correct; women with mitral stenosis are at risk for pulmonary edema, and monitoring is crucial.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • During labor, the mother with significant heart disease should be kept in a semirecumbent position with a lateral tilt.
  • Vital signs are taken frequently between contractions. Elevations in pulse rate much above 100 beats per minute (bpm) or respiratory rate above 24 breaths per minute, particularly when associated with dyspnea, may suggest impending ventricular failure.
  • The patient should have effective pain relief during labour.
  • Cut down 2nd stage of labour by instrumental delivery.
  • To decrease the risk of postpartum pulmonary edema, these patients should be placed in the sitting position following delivery as it allows more gradual adaptation to the postpartum haemodynamic changes by increasing venous pooling in the lower extremities and thereby reducing the venous return to the heart.

choices.text: Post term pregnancy & fetal growth restriction
Congenital heart disease & fetal growth restriction

questions.text: The most frequent fetal complications in patients with heart disease are:
questions.solution:
This is probably due to their relative inability to maintain an adequate uteroplacental circulation. The frequency of these problems is related to the severity of the functional impairment of the heart and the severity of the chronic tissue hypoxia.

Options:

a) Post term pregnancy & fetal growth restriction.

While post-term pregnancies can occur, they are not as common as preterm births in patients with heart disease. Fetal growth restriction is more frequently associated with compromised placental blood flow.

c) Congenital heart disease & fetal growth restriction.

Congenital heart disease can occur in offspring of mothers with heart disease, but it is not as frequent a complication as preterm birth and fetal growth restriction. The latter is more closely related to the mother's cardiovascular condition.

d) Preterm birth & congenital heart disease.

Although preterm birth is a significant concern, congenital heart disease is not as directly associated with maternal heart disease compared to fetal growth restriction. Thus, this option does not capture the most common fetal complications.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Patients with heart disease are at a higher risk for both preterm birth and fetal growth restriction. The compromised circulatory dynamics and placental insufficiency can lead to these complications.

choices.text: It is noted in 2-7% of pregnant women.
The most common causative organism is E.coli
In the absence of treatment up to 30% will develop acute pyelonephritis

questions.text: A pregnant woman undergoes a urine routine microscopy & culture in 2nd trimester with a clean-catch mid-stream sample. The report shows a single microorganism with >105 CFU/ml. She has no complaints of burning micturition, dysuria etc. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
• The woman seems to be suffering from asymptomatic bacteriuria.
  • Asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) is defined as the growth of 105 or more CFU/mL of a single uropathogen from the first void midstream clean-catch specimen in women with no urinary symptoms.
  • ASB is noted in 2-7% of pregnant women.
  • Screening for ASB must be done in all pregnant women as in the absence of treatment up to 30% will develop acute pyelonephritis. Treatment of ASB with antibiotics significantly reduces this progression to only 1%.
  • ASB is also known to be associated with increased risk of preterm delivery and low birth weight

Options:

a) It is noted in 2-7% of pregnant women.

This statement is correct. Asymptomatic bacteriuria occurs in about 2-7% of pregnant women and should be screened for during pregnancy.

b) The most common causative organism is E. coli.

This statement is also correct. E. coli is the most common pathogen responsible for urinary tract infections, including asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnant women.

d) In the absence of treatment, up to 30% will develop acute pyelonephritis.

This statement is correct. Untreated asymptomatic bacteriuria can lead to acute pyelonephritis in a significant percentage of pregnant women.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) is defined as the growth of 105 or more CFU/mL of a single uropathogen from the first void midstream clean-catch specimen in women with no urinary symptoms.

questions.text: A 22 year old G1P0 woman, 28 weeks' gestation comes up to the Obstetric OPD with complaints of burning micturition, dysuria & increased frequency of micturition. Positive nitrate dipstick test. Urine CS report awaited. She is a known case of G6PD deficiency. Which of the following drugs needs to be avoided in her treatment?
questions.solution:
• Nitrofurantoin is contraindicated in patients with G6PD (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) deficiency because it can induce hemolytic anemia due to oxidative stress, which is particularly concerning during pregnancy.
  • Cefuroxime axetil, Azithromycin, and Fosfomycin do not have the same risks and can generally be used in patients with G6PD deficiency.

Given the patient's condition, it is essential to avoid nitrofurantoin to prevent complications associated with hemolytic anemia.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • a. Cefuroxime axetil: A second-generation cephalosporin, safe in G6PD deficiency.
  • b. Azithromycin: A macrolide antibiotic, safe in G6PD deficiency.
  • c. Nitrofurantoin: Contraindicated due to risk of hemolysis in G6PD deficiency.
  • d. Fosfomycin: An antibiotic generally considered safe in G6PD deficiency.
